benefits.title: Oral branched-chain amino acids have a beneficial effect on manifestations of hepatic encephalopathy in a systematic review with meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials.
benefits.summary: Oral BCAA supplements improve manifestations of hepatic encephalopathy but have no effect on survival.

benefits.title: Effects of Branched-Chain Amino Acid (BCAA) Supplementation on the Progression of Advanced Liver Disease: A Korean Nationwide, Multicenter, Prospective, Observational, Cohort Study
benefits.summary: Long-term oral BCAA supplementation can potentially improve liver function and reduce major complications of cirrhosis in patients with advanced liver disease.

benefits.title: The Role of Branched-Chain Amino Acid Supplementation in Combination with Locoregional Treatments for Hepatocellular Carcinoma: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
benefits.summary: BCAA supplementation is associated with significantly higher post-treatment albumin levels, which may support their use in combination with locoregional treatments for hepatocellular carcinoma.

benefits.title: BCAA catabolism in brown fat controls energy homeostasis through SLC25A44
benefits.summary: BCAA supplementation is beneficial to energy expenditure and promotes systemic BCAA clearance in mice and humans, contributing to improved metabolic health.

benefits.title: Three targets of branched-chain amino acid supplementation in the treatment of liver disease.
benefits.summary: BCAA supplementation may ameliorate hepatic encephalopathy, promote liver regeneration, and improve hepatic cachexia, depending on the type of liver disease and presence of inflammation.

benefits.title: Branched‐chain amino acids
benefits.summary: BCAA supplements improved nitrogen retention and protein synthesis in patients with liver failure, but their effect on patient outcome was less clear.

benefits.title: Assessment of branched-chain amino Acid status and potential for biomarkers.
benefits.summary: BCAA supplementation spares lean body mass during weight loss, promotes wound healing, may decrease muscle wasting with aging, and may have beneficial effects in renal and liver disease.

benefits.title: Branched‐chain amino acids differently modulate catabolic and anabolic states in mammals: a pharmacological point of view
benefits.summary: BCAA supplementation or rich diets positively affect body weight regulation, muscle protein synthesis, glucose homeostasis, ageing process, and extend healthspan.

benefits.title: Update on nutritional supplementation with branched-chain amino acids
benefits.summary: BCAAs improve muscle performance, reduce protein loss, favor weight loss, reduce catabolism, and improve clinical outcomes in various diseases.
benefits.journal: Current Opinion in Clinical Nutrition and Metabolic Care

benefits.title: Effects of branched-chain amino acids and carbohydrate on fatigue during intermittent, high-intensity running.
benefits.summary: BCAA supplements do not show an added benefit on fatigue during intermittent, high-intensity running.

side effects.title: High concentration of branched‐chain amino acids promotes oxidative stress, inflammation and migration of human peripheral blood mononuclear cells via mTORC1 activation
side effects.summary: High BCAA concentrations promote oxidative stress, inflammation, and migration of human peripheral blood mononuclear cells via mTORC1 activation.

side effects.title: Branched-chain amino acid supplementation in treatment of liver cirrhosis: Updated views on how to attenuate their harmful effects on cataplerosis and ammonia formation.
side effects.summary: BCAA supplementation may have favorable effects but may also cause draining of alpha-ketoglutarate, increased glutamine content, altered neurotransmission, and ammonia formation in the gut and kidneys.

side effects.title: The effect of branched-chain amino acid supplementation on cancer treatment.
side effects.summary: BCAA supplementation may decrease malnourishment and unintentional weight loss during and after chemotherapy, but potential harms include cancer cells using BCAAs as a source of energy for growth.

side effects.title: Prognosis and safety of long-term oral branched-chain amino acids for cirrhosis: a meta-analysis
side effects.summary: Oral BCAAs improved event-free survival in cirrhotic patients, with gastrointestinal symptoms as the main side effect reported in some trials.

side effects.title: General and specialized parenteral amino acid formulations for nutrition support.
side effects.summary: BCAA solutions may cause side effects such as acidosis, hyperammonemia, hypercalciuria, and possibly bone disease and hepatotoxicity.
side effects.journal: Journal of the American Dietetic Association

side effects.title: Branched-chain amino acid supplementation in adults with cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy: a systematic review and meta-analyses
side effects.summary: Side-effects, where reported, were mild and gastrointestinal in nature.

side effects.title: Research Paper: Improving Patient Safety by Identifying Side Effects from Introducing Bar Coding in Medication Administration
side effects.summary: BCMA implementation can lead to confusion, degraded coordination between nurses and physicians, reduced workload, increased prioritization, and decreased ability to deviate from routine sequences.
side effects.journal: Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association : JAMIA

side effects.title: Recent appreciable diagnosis and therapy of liver diseases.
side effects.summary: BCAA administration improves plasma aminoacid balance, albumin, Ch-E, total cholesterol, and levels of consciousness disturbance in chronic severe liver diseases.

side effects.title: Branched-chain amino acids metabolic support in surgical patients: a randomized, controlled trial in patients with subtotal or total gastrectomy in 16 Japanese institutions.
side effects.summary: BCAA-enriched amino acid solution improves metabolism and maintains good nitrogen retention without increasing side effects compared to conventional amino acid solutions.
side effects.journal: JPEN. Journal of parenteral and enteral nutrition

side effects.title: Nitrogen retention in critically ill patients is proportional to the branched chain amino acid load
side effects.summary: There were no complications or side-effects from high dose BCAA in critically ill patients.

dosage.title: Effects of oral branched-chain amino acid granules on event-free survival in patients with liver cirrhosis.
dosage.summary: Oral BCAA supplementation at 12 g/day for 2 years improves event-free survival, serum albumin concentration, and quality of life in patients with decompensated cirrhosis.
dosage.journal: Clinical gastroenterology and hepatology : the official clinical practice journal of the American Gastroenterological Association

dosage.title: Nitrogen retention in critically ill patients is proportional to the branched chain amino acid load
dosage.summary: BCAA doses in the study were 0.16, 0.3, 0.5, and 0.7 g/kg/day, with an increased nitrogen retention effect starting at 0.5 g/kg/day.

dosage.title: A controlled trial of amino acid therapy in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
dosage.summary: BCAA dosage in the study was 12g L-leucine, 8g L-isoleucine, and 6.4g L-valine daily.

dosage.title: The effects of acute branched-chain amino acid supplementation on recovery from a single bout of hypertrophy exercise in resistance-trained athletes.
dosage.summary: BCAAs (0.087 g/kg) increased the rate of recovery in isometric strength, CMJ height, and perceived muscle soreness compared to placebo after a hypertrophy-based training session among diet-controlled athletes.
dosage.journal: Applied physiology, nutrition, and metabolism = Physiologie appliquee, nutrition et metabolisme

dosage.title: EFFECTS OF TWO DIFFERENT DOSAGE OF BCAA SUPPLEMENTATION ON SERUM INDICES OF MUSCLE DAMAGE AND SORENESS IN SOCCER PLAYERS
dosage.summary: BCAA supplementation at doses of 200 and 450 mg.kg-1 BW did not affect muscle damage and muscle soreness in soccer players during resistance exercise bouts.
dosage.journal: Pedagogics, psychology, medical-biological problems of physical training and sports

dosage.title: The Effects of Two Different Dosages of BCAA Supplementation on A Serum Indicators of Muscle Damage in Wrestlers
dosage.summary: BCAA supplementation at doses of 210 and 450 mgkg 1 body weight reduced muscle damage indices after heavy resistance exercise in wrestlers.

dosage.title: The Effects of Two Different Dosages of BCAA Supplementation on A Serum Indicators of Muscle Damage in Wrestlers
dosage.summary: BCAA dosages of 210 and 450 mgkg 1 body weight did not decrease muscle damage associated with heavy resistance exercise in wrestlers.

dosage.title: Intake of branched chain amino acids favors post-exercise muscle recovery and may improve muscle function: optimal dosage regimens and consumption conditions.
dosage.summary: The optimal dosage for post-exercise muscle recovery and/or muscle function after high-intensity resistance exercise is 2-10g BCAA/day (leucine: isoleucine: valine at 2:1:1).
dosage.journal: The Journal of sports medicine and physical fitness

dosage.title: EXPERIMENTAL SUBSTANTIATION OF THE IMMUNOSTIMULATING EFFECT OF BRANCHED-CHAIN AMINO ACIDS UNDER STRESS
dosage.summary: BCAA consumption at a dosage of 70 mg/kg body weight per day in rats during cyclic starvation causes a decrease in IL-10 and an increase in IL-1a and IL-2 levels.

dosage.title: The Effects of Chronic Branched-Chain Amino Acid Supplementation on Running Kinematics: Single Case Research
dosage.summary: BCAA supplementation was 0.08g/kg/day, which is 3.52g BCAA/day and 10.32g AA/day in this study.
